longTitle.name: longTitle
longTitle.content: An Ordinance to provide for the enforcement of contractual terms by third parties and for related matters.

subsection.content: This Ordinance may be cited as the Contracts (Rights of Third Parties) Ordinance.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Interpretation
section.def: third party (第三者), in relation to a contract, means a person who is not a party to the contract.

subsection.content: This Ordinance applies to a contract entered into on or after the date on which this Ordinance comes into operation.

subsection.leadIn: This Ordinance does not apply to any of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a bill of exchange, a promissory note or any other negotiable instrument;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a deed of mutual covenant as defined by section 2 of the Building Management Ordinance (Cap. 344);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a covenant relating to land;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: subject to subsection (3), a contract of carriage within the meaning of the Bills of Lading and Analogous Shipping Documents Ordinance (Cap. 440);

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: a contract for the carriage of goods by air governed by the Carriage by Air Ordinance (Cap. 500);

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: a letter of credit;

paragraph.name: g
h
paragraph.content: the instrument of incorporation of an open-ended fund company having effect as a contract under seal under section 112L of the Securities and Futures Ordinance (Cap. 571). (Added 16 of 2016 s. 47)

subsection.content: A third party may invoke section 4 to enforce a term of a contract referred to in subsection (2)(d) that excludes or limits liability.
This Ordinance does not confer a right on a third party to enforce a term of a contract of employment against an employee.

subsection.def: bill of exchange (匯票) means a bill of exchange within the meaning of section 3 of the Bills of Exchange Ordinance (Cap. 19);
contract of employment (僱傭合約) has the meaning given by section 2(1) of the Employment Ordinance (Cap. 57);
promissory note (承付票) means a promissory note within the meaning of section 89 of the Bills of Exchange Ordinance (Cap. 19).

section.name: s4
section.heading: Third party’s right to enforce contractual term

subsection.leadIn: A third party may enforce a term of a contract (including a term that excludes or limits liability) if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the contract expressly provides that the third party may do so; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the term purports to confer a benefit on the third party.

subsection.content: The third party must be expressly identified in the contract by name, as a member of a class or as answering a particular description.
Subsection (1)(b) does not apply if, on a proper construction of the contract, the term is not intended to be enforceable by the third party.
The enforcement of the term by a third party under this section is subject to any other term of the contract relevant to the term.
Subsection (1) applies whether or not the third party has given consideration for the term.
Subsection (1) applies to a third party even if the third party was not in existence when the contract was entered into.

There is available to a third party who enforces a term of a contract under section 4 a remedy that would have been available to the third party in an action for breach of contract if the third party had been a party to the contract.
Any law relating to the remedy applies accordingly.
To avoid doubt, the remedies available to a third party under this section include a remedy under the rules of equity.
This Ordinance does not affect a right or remedy of a third party that exists or is available apart from this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: If a third party may enforce a term of a contract under section 4, the parties to the contract may not, without the third party’s consent—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by agreement, rescind the contract; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by agreement, vary the contract so that the third party’s right under the term is altered or extinguished.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the third party has assented to the term and the promisor has received notice of the assent (whether the assent and the notice are in writing or otherwise); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the third party has relied on the term and—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the promisor is aware of the reliance; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the promisor can reasonably be expected to have foreseen that the third party would rely on the term.

subsection.leadIn: In addition, an express term of the contract prevails over subsection (1) if the term provides to the effect that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: one or more parties to the contract may rescind or vary the contract without the third party’s consent; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the third party’s consent to rescind or vary the contract is required in circumstances specified in the contract instead of those set out in subsection (2)(a) and (b).

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (3) applies only if, before the circumstances set out in subsection (2)(a) or (b) occur—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the third party is aware of the term referred to in subsection (3); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: one or more parties to the contract have taken reasonable steps to make the third party aware of the term.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Power of court to dispense with third party’s consent to rescind or vary contract

subsection.content: This section applies if a third party’s consent is required to rescind or vary a contract under section 6(1) or (3)(b).
A party to the contract may apply to the court to make an order dispensing with the third party’s consent.

subsection.leadIn: The court may make the order if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the other party or each other party to the contract agrees to rescind or vary the contract; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the court thinks it just and practicable to make the order.

subsection.content: The order may be made subject to any condition that the court thinks fit, including a condition requiring that the third party be compensated.
Subsections (2), (3) and (4) apply if a third party brings proceedings to enforce a term of a contract under section 4.

subsection.leadIn: The promisor may raise one or more of the following matters by way of defence or set-off—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: arises from or in connection with the contract and is relevant to the term; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: would have been available to the promisor by way of defence or set-off if the proceedings had been brought by the promisee;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a matter in respect of which the following conditions are met—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: an express term of the contract provides for the matter to be available to the promisor by way of defence or set-off in proceedings brought by the third party; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the matter would have been available to the promisor by way of defence or set-off if the proceedings had been brought by the promisee;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a matter that would have been available to the promisor by way of defence or set-off if the third party had been a party to the contract.

subsection.content: The promisor may raise, by way of counterclaim, a matter not arising from the contract that would have been available to the promisor by way of counterclaim against the third party if the third party had been a party to the contract.
Subsections (2)(a) and (c) and (3) are subject to any express term of the contract specifying matters not available to the promisor by way of defence, set-off or counterclaim.

In any proceedings brought against a third party, the third party may not seek to enforce under section 4 a term of a contract (including a term purporting to exclude or limit liability) if the third party could not have enforced the term had the third party been a party to the contract.
Subsection (1) applies whether the third party could not have enforced the term because of particular circumstances relating to the third party or otherwise.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Enforcement of contract by promisee
section.text: Section 4 does not affect the promisee’s right to enforce a term of the contract.

section.name: s11
section.heading: Protection of promisor from double liability

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a third party may enforce a term of a contract under section 4; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the promisor has wholly or partly performed the promisor’s obligations to the third party under the term.

subsection.content: The promisor is discharged from the obligations owed by the promisor to the promisee to the extent of having performed the same obligations to the third party.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a third party may enforce a term of a contract under section 4; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the promisee has recovered from the promisor a sum for—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the third party’s loss in relation to the term; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the expense to the promisee of making good to the third party the default of the promisor in relation to the term.

subsection.content: In any proceedings brought under section 4 before a court or arbitral tribunal by the third party, the court or arbitral tribunal must reduce any award to the third party to the extent to which it thinks appropriate to take account of the sum.
Subsection (2) applies if a third party’s right to enforce a term of a contract under section 4 is subject to an arbitration agreement.

As regards a dispute between the third party and the promisor relating to the enforcement of the term by the third party, the third party is treated as a party to the arbitration agreement for the purposes of the Arbitration Ordinance (Cap. 609).
Subsection (2) does not apply if, on a proper construction of the contract, the third party is not intended to be so treated.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a third party may enforce a term of a contract under section 4;

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: provides that one or more descriptions of dispute between the third party and the promisor is to be submitted to arbitration; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: subsection (2) does not apply in relation to the arbitration agreement.

subsection.content: If the third party enforces the arbitration agreement under section 4, then, as regards the dispute for which the arbitration agreement is enforced, the third party is treated as a party to the arbitration agreement for the purposes of the Arbitration Ordinance (Cap. 609).
The third party is so treated immediately before the third party exercises the right to enforce the arbitration agreement under section 4.

subsection.def: arbitration agreement (仲裁協議) has the meaning given by section 2(1) of the Arbitration Ordinance (Cap. 609).

subsection.leadIn: This section applies if a contract contains—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a term enforceable by a third party under section 4; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an exclusive jurisdiction clause.

subsection.content: The third party is bound by the exclusive jurisdiction clause as regards a dispute between the third party and the promisor relating to the enforcement of the term by the third party.
This section does not apply if, on a proper construction of the contract, the third party is not intended to be so bound.

subsection.def: exclusive jurisdiction clause (專有司法管轄權條款) means a clause requiring that a dispute relating to the term enforceable by the third party under section 4 be resolved only in a particular jurisdiction.

subsection.content: A third party may assign to another person a right under a term of a contract enforceable by the third party under section 4 in the same way as a party to the contract may assign a right under the contract.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the contract expressly provides otherwise; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on a proper construction of the contract, the right is personal to the third party and is not assignable.

section.name: s15
section.heading: Third party not to be treated as party to contract
section.text: Despite sections 5(1), 8(2)(c) and (3) and 9(1), a third party is not to be treated as a party to the contract for the purposes of any enactment or any instrument made under the enactment.

subsection.content: In section 4(1)(a) of the Limitation Ordinance (Cap. 347), the reference to actions founded on simple contract includes an action relating to a simple contract brought under section 4.
In section 4(3) of the Limitation Ordinance (Cap. 347), the reference to an action upon a specialty includes an action relating to a specialty brought under section 4.
